conclusion: The fixed smooth circular track ACB has a radius of 0.8m. Point A is on the same horizontal line as the center O, and the bottom point B of the circular track is on the same vertical line as the center. Point C is 0.2m vertically above point B. A block is released from rest at point A on the track, slides past point B, and then enters a sufficiently long horizontal conveyor belt. The conveyor belt is driven by a motor in the direction shown in the figure. The kinetic energy loss at the junction between the track and the conveyor belt is negligible. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the conveyor belt is 0.1, and g is taken as 10m/s².

The image shows a circular track with a radius of 0.8 m. The track is centered at point O, and point A is on the horizontal line with O. The bottom point B is on the vertical line with O. Point C is vertically above B by 0.2 m. A block is released from rest at A, slides to B, and then enters a horizontal conveyor belt.

To solve the problem, calculate the speed of the block as it slides from point A to point B using conservation of energy. Then, determine the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B using the given information and geometry of the circular track.
The block is released from rest at point A, so its initial kinetic energy is 0.
At point A, the potential energy is converted into kinetic energy as it slides to point B using conservation of energy: mgh = 1/2mv².
The vertical height from A to B is the radius of the track minus the vertical distance from B to C: h = 0.8 - 0.2 = 0.6 m.
The potential energy at A is mgh = mg × 0.6.
Setting the potential energy equal to the kinetic energy gives mg × 0.6 = 1/2mv², leading to v² = 1.2.
The speed at point B is v = √1.2 = 1.095 m/s.

To find the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B, use the fact that the block is in circular motion. The normal force is equal to the centripetal force: N = mv²/r = 1.5mg.
The ratio of the supporting force (normal force) to the gravitational force at point B is N/mg = 1.5.
The speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B is 1.095 m/s. The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is 1.5.
